content: The "Improving the Nation's Visitors' International Travel Experience Act of 2014" or the "INVITE Act of 2014" aims to create a welcoming experience at U.S. ports of entry, encourage international travelers to visit the U.S., and support jobs and economic prosperity for the nation. The term "appropriate congressional committees" in the "INVITE Act of 2014" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The term "Commissioner" refers to the Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection. The term "Global Entry Program" refers to a program described in federal regulations. The term "Model Ports of Entry Program" refers to a program established by the Secretary of Homeland Security under a specific act. SEC. 4. GLOBAL ENTRY PROGRAM EXPANSION. The Secretary of State and the Secretary of Homeland Security will explore coordinating enrollment and interview processes for individuals from trusted traveler program countries applying for a US visa and Global Entry. They will also coordinate passport application and Global Entry enrollment for eligible US citizens. A joint report is due within 6 months of the Act's enactment. Homeland Security and State Department will submit a report to Congress on expanding trusted traveler programs like Global Entry, barriers to expansion, enrollment numbers, and feasibility of coordinating enrollment with visa and passport processes. The Department of State and the Department of Homeland Security need to implement the coordinated Global Entry, visa, and passport application process. SEC. 5. STRENGTHENING THE MODEL PORTS OF ENTRY PROGRAM. Section 725 of the Implementing Recommendations of the 9/11 Commission Act of 2007 is amended to modify the program, potentially expanding it beyond the initial 20 airports. Program metrics are to be developed to ensure effectiveness. The Model Ports of Entry Program will have metrics developed by the Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection to measure its effectiveness, including customer satisfaction among passengers. A report listing program airports and their implementation details is to be submitted to congressional committees within a year of the INVITE Act of 2014 enactment. The Model Ports of Entry Grant Program, established under the INVITE Act of 2014, aims to analyze program performance, make recommendations for improving collaboration between U.S. Customs and Border Protection and airports, and consider expanding the program to more airports. Additionally, the program will award up to 10 grants on a competitive basis. The Grant Program established by the INVITE Act of 2014 aims to award up to 10 grants to airports designated by the Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection for public-private collaboration to enhance the international arrival process. Funding for the program will come from the operating budget of U.S. Customs and Border Protection, and airports must match the grant funding with non-Federal funds. Grants received are to be used for improving the grantee's facilities. The grant funding under the INVITE Act of 2014 is designated for enhancing international passenger processing facilities at airports. This includes installing informational TV monitors, improving queue management, and utilizing technology to streamline the entry process. The goal is to create a more efficient and welcoming arrival process to promote business and tourist travel to the United States. The funding cannot be used to replace airport improvement projects funded by other sources. The INVITE Act of 2014 provides grant funding for airport improvement projects, specifically for enhancing international passenger processing facilities. Grantees are required to establish public-private partnership working groups with U.S. Customs and Border Protection, which may include representatives from the travel and tourism industry. The INVITE Act of 2014 provides grant funding for airport improvement projects, focusing on enhancing international passenger processing facilities. Grantees must establish public-private partnership working groups with U.S. Customs and Border Protection, involving various sectors such as hotels, theme parks, rental cars, tour operators, travel distribution, retail, State tourism authority, local convention and visitors authority, cultural interest groups, and event management. These groups collaborate to share best practices for improving the international arrivals process. The INVITE Act of 2014 provides grant funding for airport improvement projects, focusing on enhancing international passenger processing facilities. Grantees must establish public-private partnership working groups with U.S. Customs and Border Protection to improve the international arrivals process. The Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection administers the Model Ports of Entry Grant Program and selects grantees based on established criteria. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to working groups under this program. The Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection administers the Model Ports of Entry Grant Program and establishes criteria for selecting grantees. Metrics are set to determine program effectiveness. A report must be submitted within 2 years, detailing program status, metrics for measuring effectiveness, and an analysis comparing program results with established metrics. The Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection oversees the Model Ports of Entry Grant Program, setting criteria for grantees and measuring program effectiveness. Recommendations include expanding the program to more airports and outlining improvements to be made. SEC. 6. U.S. CUSTOMS AND BORDER PROTECTION WAIT TIME METRICS. The Commissioner must submit an annual report to congressional committees, including data on passenger wait times, analysis of Customs and Border Protection performance, and updates on reducing processing times at ports of entry. Additionally, the Commissioner is required to publicly disseminate wait times. The Commissioner is mandated to post current wait times for processing international passengers at US airports and land ports on the Customs and Border Protection website for easy access. This information must be continuously updated during operating hours. The Commissioner is required to report to Congress within a year on efforts to enhance technology in the international arrivals process, improve passenger screening at US ports of entry, develop new technologies, and streamline the processing of inbound international travelers while enhancing security. Additionally, there is a focus on increasing transparency in Department of Homeland Security customer service enhancements. The Secretary of Homeland Security is mandated to collect and analyze traveler feedback to improve customer service practices, ensure a welcoming environment, and enhance the image of the United States globally. This feedback will be coordinated across relevant agencies, reported quarterly, and used to develop best practices including cultural sensitivity and diversity training. The Secretary of Homeland Security will report traveler feedback to the Department of Transportation for publication in the Air Travel Consumer Report. The U.S. Customs and Border Protection INFO Center staffing will be sufficient to keep caller wait times under 10 minutes.
